<body>

<style type="text/css">
.main-container {
  max-width: 940px;
  margin-left: auto;
  margin-right: auto;
}
code {
  color: inherit;
  background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.04);
}
img { 
  max-width:100%; 
  height: auto; 
}
</style>
<div class="container-fluid main-container">




<div id="osmplotr-build-status" class="section level1">
<h1>osmplotr <a href="https://travis-ci.org/mpadge/osmplotr"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," alt="Build Status" /></a></h1>
<p>R package to produce visually impressive customisable images of urban areas from OpenStreetMap (OSM) data, using data downloaded from the <a href="http://overpass-api.de/">overpass api</a>. This map shows building polygons for a small portion of central London, U.K., and was made with the following easy steps:</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="map1" /></p>
<ol style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>Specify the bounding box for the desired region</li>
</ol>
<pre class="r"><code>bbox &lt;- c(-0.15,51.5,-0.1,51.52) </code></pre>
<ol start="2" style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>Download the desired data—in this case, all building perimeters.</li>
</ol>
<pre class="r"><code>dat_B &lt;- extract_osm_objects (key=&quot;building&quot;, bbox=bbox)</code></pre>
<ol start="3" style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>Initiate an <code>osm_basemap</code> with desired background (<code>bg</code>) colour</li>
</ol>
<pre class="r"><code>plot_osm_basemap (xylims=get_xylims (bbox), bg=&quot;gray20&quot;, file=&quot;map1.png&quot;)</code></pre>
<ol start="4" style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>Add desired plotting objects in the desired colour.</li>
</ol>
<pre class="r"><code>add_osm_objects (dat_B, col=&quot;gray40&quot;)</code></pre>
<ol start="5" style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>Close graphics device to finish</li>
</ol>
<pre class="r"><code>graphics.off ()</code></pre>
<div id="a-simple-map" class="section level2">
<h2>A simple map</h2>
<p>Simple maps can be made by overlaying different kinds of OSM data in different colours:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>dat_H &lt;- extract_osm_objects (key=&quot;highway&quot;, bbox=bbox)
dat_P &lt;- extract_osm_objects (key=&quot;park&quot;, bbox=bbox)
dat_G &lt;- extract_osm_objects (key=&quot;landuse&quot;, value=&quot;grass&quot;, bbox=bbox)</code></pre>
<pre class="r"><code>plot_osm_basemap (xylims=get_xylims (bbox), bg=&quot;gray20&quot;, file=&quot;map2.png&quot;)
add_osm_objects (dat_B, col=&quot;gray40&quot;)
add_osm_objects (dat_H, col=&quot;gray80&quot;)
add_osm_objects (dat_P, col=&quot;darkseagreen&quot;)
add_osm_objects (dat_G, col=&quot;darkseagreen1&quot;)
graphics.off ()</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="map2" /></p>
</div>
<div id="highlighting-selected-areas" class="section level2">
<h2>Highlighting selected areas</h2>
<p><code>osmplotr</code> is primarily intended as a data visualisation tool, particularly through enabling selected regions to be highlighted. Regions can be defined according to simple point boundaries:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>pts &lt;- sp::SpatialPoints (cbind (c (-0.128, -0.138, -0.138, -0.128),
                             c (51.502, 51.502, 51.515, 51.515)))</code></pre>
<p>and then both buildings and parks highlighted with different colour schemes. The <code>col_extra</code> parameter defines the colour of the remaining, background area.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>plot_osm_basemap (xylims=get_xylims (bbox), bg=&quot;gray20&quot;, file=&quot;map3.png&quot;)
group_osm_objects (dat_B, groups=pts, col=&quot;orange&quot;, col_extra=&quot;gray40&quot;, 
                   colmat=FALSE, boundary=1)
add_osm_objects (london$dat_P, col=&quot;darkseagreen1&quot;)
group_osm_objects (london$dat_P, groups=pts, col='darkseagreen1',
                   col_extra='darkseagreen', colmat=FALSE, boundary=0)
graphics.off ()</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="map3" /></p>
<p>Or may highlighted in dark-on-light:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>plot_osm_basemap (xylims=xylims, bg=&quot;gray95&quot;, file=&quot;map4.png&quot;)
group_osm_objects (dat_B, groups=pts, col=&quot;gray40&quot;, col_extra=&quot;gray85&quot;,
                   colmat=FALSE, boundary=1)
group_osm_objects (dat_H, groups=pts, col=&quot;gray20&quot;, col_extra=&quot;gray70&quot;,
                   colmat=FALSE, boundary=0)
group_osm_objects (dat_HP, groups=pts, col=&quot;gray10&quot;, col_extra=&quot;white&quot;,
                   colmat=FALSE, boundary=0)
graphics.off ()</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="map4" /></p>
<div id="highlighting-clusters" class="section level3">
<h3>Highlighting clusters</h3>
<p><code>group_osm_objects</code> also enables plotting an entire region as a group of spatially distinct clusters of defined colours. First define some range groups:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>ngroups &lt;- 12
x &lt;- bbox [1] + runif (ngroups) * (bbox [3] - bbox [1])
y &lt;- bbox [2] + runif (ngroups) * (bbox [4] - bbox [2])
groups &lt;- cbind (x, y)
groups &lt;- apply (groups, 1, function (i) 
              sp::SpatialPoints (matrix (i, nrow=1, ncol=2)))
# Then create small rectangles around each pts
groups &lt;- lapply (groups, function (i)
               {
                   x &lt;- sp::coordinates (i) [1] + c (-0.002, 0.002, 0.002,
                                                     -0.002)
                   y &lt;- sp::coordinates (i) [2] + c (-0.002, -0.002, 0.002,
                                                     0.002)
                   sp::SpatialPoints (cbind (x, y))
               })</code></pre>
<p>Calling <code>group_osm_objects</code> with <code>col_extra=NA</code> (or <code>NULL</code>) forces all points not immediately within defined groups to be allocated to the nearest groups, and thus produces an inclusive grouping extending across an entire area.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>plot_osm_basemap (xylims=get_xylims (bbox), bg='gray20', file='map5.png')
group_osm_objects (dat_B, groups=groups, col_extra=NA, make_hull=FALSE,
                   colmat=TRUE, lwd=3)
graphics.off ()</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="map5" /></p>
</div>
<div id="highlighting-areas-bounded-by-named-highways" class="section level3">
<h3>Highlighting areas bounded by named highways</h3>
<p>An alternative way of defining highlighted groups is by naming the highways encircing desired regions.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>highways &lt;- c ('Regent.St', 'Oxford.St', 'Shaftesbury')
highways &lt;- highways2polygon (highways=highways, bbox=bbox)</code></pre>
<p>and then passing the SpatialPolygon returned by <code>highways2polygon</code> to <code>group_osm_objects</code>:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>plot_osm_basemap (xylims=get_xylims (bbox), bg='gray20', file='map6.png')
group_osm_objects (dat_B, groups=highways, boundary=1,
                   col_extra='gray40', colmat=FALSE, col='orange')
group_osm_objects (dat_H, groups=highways, boundary=0,
                   col_extra='gray70', colmat=FALSE, col='darkorange2')
graphics.off ()</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="map6" /></p>
<p>… see package vignette for a lot more detail and further capabilities.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>


</div>
